reviews.review_title: Its not a bad film, just a bad conversion
reviews.content: Being a film lover, and even being able to enjoy watching even a good B movie, I rate this as a better than average game conversion movie.It has a nice budget, plenty of action, a story than generally makes sense, some fairly well known faces and even starts off fairly promising.The main rub is that it tries to make the film appear almost every-day believable, which just doesn't work with it also trying to be a totally fictional game conversion where there are special powers all over the place.Toning down certain abilities, and omitting characters from the game will always upset hardcore gaming fans, which is a shame as the film really isn't all that bad.My biggest bug-bear is the directing. If you are going to do an action movie then pick an action director and style it that way, but if you are going to try and throw in romance, military and martial arts as well then at least pick a director who has a familiarity with those genres.What you get here is a film that works in places but fails in others, because the director has no idea of how to shoot scenes with police or the armed forces and yet insist on including them in the plot. Mistake!

reviews.review_title: Great movie
reviews.content: This was a great movie and who underrates it?? If only it hit the theaters... I've watched this movie so many times that I actually have to buy another dvd of it cause the other was scratched. Kristin is always such a great character in every movie and my fave.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the worst movie to hit the big screen since.....well a while
reviews.content: I would like to start off with a little background, so i don't appear biased. I am a huge movies fan, and will watch almost anything that might be stimulating, and i have been playing video games including street fighter since the first Nintendo entertainment system.I had seen the original streetfighter, which was just below average, so i was quite happy when they opted to remake it. This was clearly misplaced optimism, the legend of Chun-li is such a poor film, that i consider the fact that it made the big screen, cunning and deceptive.The movie has the feel of having being shot using an old tea bag as filter, and a camera crew comprising three people. i would even allow Jean-Claude to complain about this movie, because the previous one was better, and that statement speaks volumesWith that said, had the film had it's full compliment of camera crew, it still would not have rescued the weak plot, and even poorer performances. The cast itself was OK, but when you mix underrated actors from your typical blood and guts films, with semi-household names the likes of Michael Clarke Duncan, their average performance resemble the rest of the poor actors.another corny thing i need to mention, every time Bison alights on the screen, a sound clip or a tiger is played???? HIS NAME IS BISON.This movie is horrible, really poor, the locations were pretty nice, but that was about it, i was half expecting Steven Seagal to have a Cameo. This movie will cause cataracts

reviews.review_title: A new level of low
reviews.content: There is absolutely nothing good about this movie.The special effects were awful, i could do better in Adobe After Effects.The script was bad, the plot and moral contradicted each other, the lines were corny and made me feel nausea. I truly feel bad for the actors, there were many well-known actors in it and this movie does not do them justice.I didn't expect much of the movie, but this was so bad that if i hadn't been too lazy to put an another movie on i would've turned it off before the end.I don't recommend anyone to watch this, even with your expectations turned down to a minimum you will still feel like someone has tried to feed you horse dung.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst movie I've seen
reviews.content: The plot is pretty loose: kidnapping, some almost spiritual journey to beat the bad guys without being angry, some random sub-plot about the "white rose" which didn't add much/make much sense, in my opinion.Fight scenes were pretty standard for poorly rated martial arts films. Also included some pointless Matrix-style stunts.There were a few actors I recognised but this film didn't do much for them. It was all pretty cringe.I especially find films that insert themselves into another culture, especially commenting on that country's politics/social issues, are even worse when they use mostly American actors.

reviews.review_title: I feel bad for Kristin Kreuk
reviews.content: Kreuk did pretty good. When I first heard that she was cast for the part of Chun Li I really didn't think that she could pull it off. But, she did quite well; even during the fight sequences. Unfortunately, she had no support in cast nor plot. This movie made absolutely no sense. No sense whatsoever. I just don't understand why a piano playing school girl is chosen by the "order if the web" to dismantle the biggest crime syndicate in the world. And there was no attempt to even explain so. Along with lacking information and background, the plot also lacked in any realism. Why would a piano playing school girl leave home ( a mansion and several servants ) to become a homeless wanderer in bangkok because some mysterious scroll told her to. Chris Kline as Charlie Nash was a horrid performance. Kline should stick to his roles in teenage comedy dramas. His sad attempt at playing a bad ass cop was laughable and I have lost a lot of respect for him as an actor after this movie.

reviews.review_title: It's not Street Fighter, and it absolutely has nothing to do with Chun-Li or the fighting game itself
reviews.content: Honestly I have nothing more to say about this awful movie. I myself have actually enjoyed playing Street Fighter games because their movesets are very simple to pull off and most of it's roster just has the perfect kind of appearance they would also look for most of Capcom's gaming lineup.So this is based on Street Fighter's iconic female fighter Chun-Li, this movie is focused around her and the revenge she gets at M. Bison for killing her father. And asides that this movie tries so hard to explain her story throughout the film, it seems to fall off so hard and panned.The casting is pretty god-awful and horrible and it seems to me like they added Kristen Kreuk to play as Chun-Li. Even though she was a lot better playing as Lana Lang in Smallville, I feel that her role as the popular female fighter is an absolute mis-cast because she happens to be a mixed-race (she is Chinese Canadian) for the Street Fighter character who is fully Chinese, at one point in this movie she puts on her trademark hairbuns and wears a blue dress (not even a qipao), but then the rest of this movie shows her wearing black or other clothing that doesn't match Chun-Li at all. Neal McDonough is even worse for playing as M. Bison because he looks nothing like his video game counterpart, doesn't even wear his iconic outfit, at least Raul Julia had dark hair for the role of M. Bison back when he played as him before his death. Although we can safely say that Julia's role of the villain had more better experience than that of McDonough who's hardly even acted out like Bison especially with that dumb fake Scottish or Irish accent. Chris Klein and Moon Bloodgood that both played as Charlie Nash and Maya (who is basically C. Viper from SFIV) don't even look like their video game counterparts and just go off as useless detectives in scenes from this movie. They're using guns most of the time and I don't know if they would've known that this movie is called Street Fighter and they should've been using their hand-to-hand combat besides using firearms for most of the movie. Two other one of Bison's Shadaloo men Balrog and Vega were played by the late Michael Clark Duncan and Taboo (singer of the Black Eyed Peas). Both of their roles also had major flaws. For Duncan on his role as Balrog goes off using firearms and can't even throw punches at one of his opponents just because he's a boxer. For Taboo on his role as Vega shows that he's too short to play the role and is also Native-Mexican while Vega in the games is actually tall and Spaniard. Overall the one interesting role I would somewhat like is Robin Shou who you might remember him as Liu Kang in Mortal Kombat from 1995 and plays a small role as a pirate leader in DOA: Dead or Alive. He plays the role of Gen who is Chun-Li's master and spends his time training and also fighting alongside with her in the movie. The one thing that throws me off is when he pronounces Ryu as RAI-YOO and not REE-YOO or if you were to roll that "R" with the name it would've sounded more accurate.The fight scenes in this movie somehow feel ok at times but then they would show the scene where Chun-Li would actually kill one of those guys in this movie especially when she's a police officer! And not only that, there are some brutal scenes that make it a little hard to watch just because they would slap on the Street Fighter name on the title of this film!The special effects in this movie are absolutely the worst ones yet. There are times when you know that the bullet shots are digital effects without using prop firearms. And the Kikoken scene is the most terrible cheap special effect of all-time. It's not even colored blue in the games, and the appearance on it looked like it was taken from an old 90s computer graphics that still looks awful today.The quotes in this movie are probably the worst, no where near as corny as what we usually would hear in Street Fighter the Movie with JCVD and Raul Julia. That movie at least was cheesy and had fun moments which still shows some better word quotes from characters like Guile like when he gives out a speech or M. Bison talking about raiding Chun-Li's village ending with the phrase "For me, it was Tuesday". But in Legend of Chun-Li, it seems their lines were murky and also uninspired like Bison would tell Chun-Li that her father is the milk of his business and would finish with "But even milk has an expiration date". I mean how would you not know that milk goes bad all the time! Especially all the other characters quotes feel so flat and terrible in terms of a scene they would be mentioning.Ok so this movie of it's own would think that Rose (and yes I'm talking about Rose from Street Fighter games) is the daughter of M. Bison. There is no blood-related connection between them in the games. Rose is in fact Italian from the fighting game she originates and has a fortune telling ability. This movie's version of (White) Rose is nothing more than coming off as Russian (due to the language she spoke) and is never actually a fighter.Overall this movie is nothing more than a pretty bad reception and a god-awful superhero like fighting game adaptation. Everything about this movie is so bland, most of the characters in this movie don't even look or dress like their appearances from the video games because they're all wearing black for the majority of the film, the special effects are all so cheaply made like it's an independent movie despite being released by 20th Century Fox (now known as 20th Century Studios), the acting and writing is so piss-poor with each character's lines saying something nonsensical, and all about this movie is that they were planning to have a sequel with Ryu and Ken Masters. Unfortunately it didn't happen and I'm just so glad that the sequel of this misstep of an adaptation would never have been made, it could've been much worse.This movie's runtime is about 96 minutes, well apparently the deleted scenes included multiple scenes that were cut from the final product! One being a cameo scene with the producer of Hyde Park Entertainment, Ashok Amritraj. And at the very end is suppose to be I think a post-credit scene where the White Rose is at the police station then all of a sudden her eyes show that she's possessed almost thinking she's taken M. Bison's aura around her. But again overall I'm just glad that a sequel had to be cut out for this abomination.It's hard to believe that the writer for this movie would later go on to write the live action Disney Jungle Book movie from 2016 and of course probably the best drama movie of all-time, Top Gun Maverick! It's incredible he went from a rocky start to a smooth flowing safe trail. I recommend watching those movies instead, but stay FAR AWAY FROM LEGEND OF CHUN-LI!! I recommend axing it or Hadouken it in flames!

reviews.review_title: (Unintentionally) The Comedy Of The Year!
reviews.content: You know how they say that some movies are so bad that they're good? Well, "Street Fighter: The Legend Of Chun-Li" may be so brain-boilingly awful that it's actually incredible. Take pretty much everything that you know about the video game this is based on, and throw it all out of the window because that's exactly what the makers of this movie did!Now have a think about the following question. If you had been orphaned as a small baby in Thailand, what accent would you have after growing up there? Well, according to the makers of this movie, it would be Irish. If you're looking for an explanation to this, the movie intelligently provides one by informing you that the character in question (Bison, for those of you who know your Street Fighter games) had an Irish mother.Erm...right! This is a movie in which we have a renegade cop called Nash who has obviously never had the time to look up the word 'cliche'. With two day stubble, he swaggers around his scenes shouting things like "What orders?" or growling at computer screens. At one point he walks straight up to the camera to recite plot-moving dialogue straight to the audience with a knowing wink.This movie is awful. Absolutely terrible. There is even a scene in which Chun Li actually has a sexy dance-off with a lesbian enemy. I swear to God, that I'm not joking about this. What's even better is that this scene ends with a character asking renegade cop Nash 'Are you going to tell me or should I guess?' with Nash growling back in a Dirty Harry voice (whilst squinting like somebody playing a parody in one of those "Epic Movie" abominations) 'Go ahead and guess.' It's as though Chris Klein (who plays Nash) was the only actor who realised that this entire movie was a joke and decided to pretend he was in a comedy.I can't recommend this movie enough if you get any amusement over cinematic car crashes.Terrible. Just terrible.

reviews.review_title: Not even worth a penny!
reviews.content: The movie sucks big time. Being a fan of Street Fighter games, I had high expectations but it all ended within 15 min. I waited desperately for something. And then I was waiting for the movie to get over.It lack in almost all the departments. The dialogs were worse than even imagined, a 5 yr old could have done better job with it. The direction is so so bad that I would like to request Mr. Andrzej Bartkowiak to please have a disclaimer that it must not be watched.Lastly, I would just like to highlight my rating that gives 2. The only reason why it doesn't deserve 1 is because of some tolerable action stunts that otherwise are quite normal but for a movie of this low level seems good. So people if you want to be a fan of Street Fighter franchisee please DON'T WATCH THE MOVIE>

reviews.content: to all the people that seen this movie and liked it... damn i hope you were doing something with your man or women in that matter and weren't paying attention...anyone else see it is horrible that see kills BISON?? let alone hurts him.i its freaking embarrassing to see all the things that went wrong GEN doesn't look like him... balrog and bison charlie all this was bad i'm done ready to attack someone over it I wish and hope no one else sees this movie movies that are suppose to help other know more about the games there suppose to portray are not doing it leaving others confused and the people that love the game or book they took from and killed it...

reviews.review_title: Entertaining
reviews.content: A little silly at times, especially in scenes with the Chris Kline. He is a stooge. But Kristen is the most perfect little hottie in my lifetime, so to me, it's worth watching. Also the fight scenes are choreographed well for this type of movie.

reviews.review_title: Just as ridiculous as anything Uwe Boll has done.
reviews.content: I went to see this movie having easily the lowest expectations possible figuring that if I had low expectations, the movie may surprise me and be decent. Needless to say, this movie was worse than those expectations.The movie was a clichéd mess filled with terrible editing, terrible acting, terrible dialog, terrible effects, and a terrible story to boot.Bison in this is your typical crime boss operating out of Bangkok, instead of an evil mastermind whatever-the-hell he is in the games. The writers essentially turned M. Bison from a legit-badass into the movie version of Lex Luthor. The entire reason he does what he does in the film, is to make super-condos on waterfront property in bangkok for the super rich.Michael Clark Duncan is decent, you can tell he had fun making this movie, unfortunately his lines usually get cut off half the time, or he doesn't actually say more than two lines within a 20 minute time-span. His first fight scene was actual decent, but the others were really lack-luster.Kristin Kruek wasn't that bad as Chun-li, like with the others I believe she did the best she could with what she had to work with, which wasn't much.Now I did say the acting was terrible, and I stand by this, I say the acting was terrible because the writing was even worse. The dialog was ridiculous and unbelievable and sounded so forced coming from the actors that it ruined any chance of immersion and turned what tried to be a series kung-fu film into your typical sci-fi original garbage only with worse writing.The fight scenes in the film are sparse, the fight with Vega lasts a good 2 minutes, which wouldn't have been a problem if they hadn't hyped Vega up so much within the film. I can't tell if the fight scenes were bad because of the poor job of editing them together, or if the people in the fight scenes were just that terrible at the fight scenes themselves.The special effects were stale and seemed like they were from 2002, instead of using pyrotechnics to blow up a building, they instead use cgi explosions, this wouldn't be a problem if the cgi explosions didn't look like it was a cgi-explosion.Then there were spots in the film that just make no sense. In order for Bison to become truly evil, he stabbed his pregnant wife in the stomach with his hands and took out the baby inside of a cave, and apparently transferred the good part of his soul into the baby. This was easily the most WTF moment within the entire film, the actor playing young Bison looked creepy as hell, and I couldn't tell if he was going to eat the baby or not. I'm not entirely sure why I brought that up, but it was just weird.There is a lot more I could say about this movie. If you're expecting a good video game movie, you will be disappointed. If you're expecting a decent kung-fu flick, you will be disappointed. If you're expecting a decent action movie, you will be disappointed.If you're looking for a movie that is so ridiculous you and your friends(I suggest bringing friends) can't help but laugh and make fun of the movie throughout. You're in for a treat.There is a lot more I could say about this movie, a lot more negative, not a lot of positive.But like I said just a minute ago. Go into the movie expecting to see some bad acting, bad writing, bad action, don't take it seriously and have a few friends along so you can MST3K the film. Then you'll feel like you hadn't wasted your money.

reviews.review_title: Were they TRYING to make an awful movie?
reviews.content: I don't even know where to begin listing everything that's wrong with this movie. I guess I should start with the fact that Kristen Kreuk is starring in a movie about a martial artist (although wu shu is more of a performance art than a martial art – but that's another story) despite the fact she is utterly incapable of moving gracefully. However, she can't take all of the blame for the poor fighting as the choreography was atrocious (people getting knocked out by being kicked in the leg?) and the multiple interrogations were intrinsically stupid (Chun Li asks question, bad guy resists, Chun Li punches bad guy and bends his arm funny, bad guys tells her everything – all in the course of ten seconds.) But when you put her together with Chris Klein, it creates a void of acting ability that would have made it impossible to buy into the plot if the plot were actually plausible. The only decent performances in the entire movie were by Neil McDonough as Bison and, surprisingly, Moon Bloodgood as a detective – but that's made moot by the fact that the writer has apparently never heard actual humans converse before, so the dialogue wouldn't be worth listening to even if it were delivered well. Plus, Bison's evil plan is to . . . build quality housing and sell it to the rich? He became head of an evil empire for that? Also, he wipes out other crime families to be able to do it and is doing it because he wants a better life for his daughter – if they hadn't repeatedly called him the head of a criminal organization, I might've thought he was just a decent hardworking businessman/superhero.It seems the entire movie was just filler until they could put the inevitable final confrontation on screen. And when she threw a fireball in that final confrontation, it was probably the worst special effect ever seen in a big-budget movie. The only way I could imagine anyone enjoying this movie is if they appreciate watching has-been actors ham-fist their way through a script that was written by someone with almost no knowledge of Street Fighter over the course of one booze-filled weekend.

reviews.review_title: This is a joke
reviews.content: First let me say.....the action part in this movie was good....how ever this move had nothing to do with street fighter other than the names.Chun li father die when she was a child Gen was an old man who learn chun li in her youth Balrog was a boxer ETC!!Chun li performance in this picture was good she fought well and stuff however vega was more ruthless than that by far...bison was the only decent character in the movie..... But he died real petty....So my review would be nice action film.. but it was a action film with street fighter names. What is street fighter without KEN AND RYU...........PLEASE!!! this is a joke

reviews.review_title: Not that bad
reviews.content: I am no where NEAR a Street Fighter fan. I haven't played any of the games, I never saw the 94 film, and I didn't care that Street Fighter 4 was coming out when everybody was drooling over it. Give me Mortal Kombat any day.But because a friend of mine bought the 3 disc Blu-Ray when he doesn't have a Blu-Ray player, I received this film (among a few others) for free. So I gave it a whirl.I feel that Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun Li is a fine Martial Arts film with a nice pinch of Fantasy. The Characters were all likable, hate-able, or just plain repulsive. That is the actual spirit of the Character... NOT their acting. The acting was decent and believable.So would I watch Street Fighter again? sure... Would I become a die hard Street Fighter junkie because of this film. Not a chance.5/10

reviews.review_title: Total crap.
reviews.content: I totally understand the urge to create something different out of the title as excluding "Ryu vs. Ken" or "team-up vs. Shadoloo", and to pick a SF Alpha weighted-roster. And although this is getting a little lame after Marvel adaptations, I also appreciate the attempt to furnish the chars with a darker, modern, casual look and attitude.But such a dim witted plot is unacceptable. The title is "legend", but all we get to see is a teenager depressed enough to leave all her wealthy and satisfactory life behind in order to pursue Gen (why? a mystery even Chun-Li doesn't know), listening to the psychedelic bablings of a street fortune teller.Purchasing slum lots illegally and opening them to luxury construction is quite an absurd line of business to choose for any SF boss. But killing all shareholders to acquire all shares? Very clever indeed...Side character development is none, so there s not much to talk about. The general flow implies that Balrog is a loyal scum, but why? to what extent? None hinted... Vega is supposed to be an ice cold mercenary, we should have felt his cold breath on the neck of our girl. Should have seen something like Sabretooth, Agt. Smith or Cromartie, but instead we have seen monkeyish Taboo getting his ass kicked by a teenage girl at the first round, without even being able to cut her! She hanged him like a flag for gods sake...Chris Klein and Moon Bloodgood duo is possibly the dumbest crime investigation partners you may ever see. They have no significant effect on the general plot whatsoever. But ironically enough, after their task-force is dismissed (thanks to Shadoloo pulling a few strings), the two gets to be able to assign six fully equipped vehicles carrying a SWAT team, for a midnight raid operation.I don't think any movie from any genre could reach the stupidity level of the first SF movie. But this one was really close.

reviews.review_title: Big Let Down !!WARNING SPOILERS!!!
reviews.content: Typical, a game made into a movie, why do they always end up like this, to cut a long story short, this film sucks, the writer sucks and so does the director, i hope the critics lay into them hardcore, the first movie, with JCVD was actually more entertaining and true to the game, this is nothing but a shot at trying to make bank off a popular franchise yet again.PatheticSPOILER WARNING FROM HERE! There cannot be a true sequel, as both balrog and Bison are killed Did they even do there research about street fighter?!, bison killed by chun Li, what the hell, give me some bank, ill make a better movie

reviews.review_title: it was OK? okish
reviews.content: Personally love street fighter but you have to cut the movie some slack. If it did add too many characters then the plot would make less sense than it already is. The martial arts scenes are not that bad they actually look cool. Although the editing on the "spinning bird kick" could have been better. I guess I love the street fighter series too much to actually hate this movie. Plus the movie would be way better if it was longer but they just didn't have the budget and the street fighter series has too much in the storyline to match the movie so the plot was OK for not being canon to the games. At least we can say that this movie was a little better than the tekken movie right? Overall it was ehh.

reviews.review_title: Such a great fun-bad movie
reviews.content: They completely change the characters origin, then the movie follows a story that would make sense to the original origin. Every change to the story they made made their movie more convoluted. Amazing.

reviews.review_title: Its worst than the original, ......... i cant believe i just said that !!!
reviews.content: Awful, bad acting, bad storyline, bad fight choreography and Chris Kline looks like he's trying to pop a turd every scene he's in ! The film just does not work on any level and the storyline feels if it has been lifted straight out of an abandoned Manga effort,even the lesbian scene falls flat on its face. Don't even bother with this one guys i'm just happy i seen it for free !!Ps. - check out the original animated movie or Alpha movies if u looking for decent SF lore looks like all hope is gone for the big screen.Thanks for reading Laters

reviews.review_title: The 1994 movie is a masterpiece compared to this trash!! Avoid!!
reviews.content: Street Fighter: The Legend Of Chun-Li was intended to be a reboot in place of a sequel. It was intended to be more faithful to the games unlike the previous movie, but derailed. The only connections to the game are that Balrog and Vega work for Bison, and that Bison is in charge of Shadaloo. But other than that, you can barely recognize these characters from the game as they do not sport their counterparts' costumes. In fact, we only see a small handful instead of a large ensemble of the characters from the game, leaving this movie flat and dull. I guess the writers could not accommodate them into the script without any real motivation. The worst part of this movie is Chun-Li's monologue, with a non-Asian (Oriental) actress playing her. A Chinese young girl grows up into a Latina woman and yet does not even don her counterpart's costume. (I think they took her video game counterpart's resemblance to a Caucasian too seriously.) This 'reboot' is a colossal letdown, and it hurts to watch every minute of it. If you remember Bison from the game, you will not recognize him in this reboot: he sports a business attire instead of a dictator general's attire from the game. Even the 1994 movie stays true, with the villain donning the suit throughout the flick. I have seen fight scenes in this reboot which are so unrealistic that it would be insulting to think that they would cause any real injury. Even on an algebraically larger budget (inflation not taken into consideration), this reboot fails largely on sticking to the game. However if inflation is taken into account, the 1994 movie is more expensive than the 2008 movie; thus no expenses were spared in the former. Street Fighter In 1994: Budget: $35 million Box office intake: >$99 millionIn 2014: rate of inflation = 8% Budget: $163,133,500 Box office intake: $461,434,757. 24Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li In 2008: Budget: $50 million Box office intake: >$12 millionIn 2014: Budget: $79,343,716 Box office intake: $19,042,491.88So where did they go wrong? How could they botch it up? The first movie was campy but more faithful to the game at the time, but this reboot was a dreadful hit-and-miss. I would not criticize the first movie, featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Raul Julia, any more than this crud, as watching it proves my point. I bet the first movie will be treated as a superior live-action adaptation of a video game to the second one (although Street Fighter II: The Animated Movie remains the overall best adaptation of the video game). I can see why Street Fighter is regarded as Citizen Kane compared with Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li.

reviews.review_title: Its just not good
reviews.content: Honestly this movie goes down the same path as DragonBall Evolution while being a street fighter movie, it follows its own stupid story, M.Bison wasn't a leader of a drug ring or whatever they said he was and to be honest, i don't like the actor portraying Bison, also what the heck was wrong with Vega? everything was wrong with Vega.... and not to mention... NO RYU? yeah there is no Ryu, no Ken, heck there isn't even a Dan... Im not even going to mention the fact that Chun Li looks white, also where is Akuma, Blanka, or even any of the other Street Fighter characters? in conclusion, stop...just stop it and don't make another bad movie based off a video game... Im looking at you Hit-man:Agent 47

reviews.review_title: Pretty disappointing
reviews.content: Ew, I'm sorry, it's a bad movie. The fight scenes are horrible, Kreuk's Chinese was pretty bad, and so was her acting in this movie, I don't want to bash her, but she did not fit the character's tough personality. It was pretty corny. Sigh, don't watch it if you expect to spend some quality time with someone, because you'll just spend your time complaining how stupid this or that is. I'd advise watching this movie, ONLY if you're a dedicated fan of street fighter, in which case you'll probably go "oh man, he/she's so cool! This is my all-time fave movie." if not (meaning you are a normal movie watching person, that doesn't really know much about the actors/director) then it's not a very good movie.

reviews.review_title: Just not right
reviews.content: Casting was horrible. Chun-Li was my favorite character from the game. Kristin Kreuk does not have her thighs. She never wore the short dress as in the game. She only had her hair in two bobs once in the movie. Chun Li is supposed to have amazing thighs, two bobs, sort of pale, and she is supposed to yell yep-yep while she is fighting. She also had way to many flying fighting moves. With todays technology they could of made her moves glow in every fight. Bison never wore his uniform and did not perform any of his sliding moves. Balrog was horribly casted with Duncan. Vega is supposed to be like 7 feet tall. I am just so mad at this movie I could just beat up the scriptwriter/director and whoever did the casting needs to be shot. The first half of the movie should of been back story and the second half should of been a worldwide tournament. How hard is this? The back of the DVD states "round one fight". This is misleading as hell.

reviews.review_title: Street Fighter: Legend of FAIL!
reviews.content: Is this movie better than the Street Fighter movie with JCVD? Yes and No...Yes because there was better acting and no because it's 2009 and they still can't seem to get it right. You would think they would of learned to make a better Street Fighter movie by now. It really all comes down to storyline and Ryu Story would make the most sense. It's what the games were based on so why make the movie on a different character? It almost makes me think Hollywood is racist cause the first movie was on Guile( who was played by a french guy)...great casting there...and now this street fighter, Chun-Li is played but Kristen Kreuk...While I really didn't have much of problem with Kristen playing Chun-Li, I think they could of found someone more true to Chun-Li's character. They should of started with Ryu's Story without messing it up and then maybe down the line had the story of Chun-Li. This was bad planning on the studio's part. How can they wish for a sequel when this movie's numbers suck. No one wants to watch another butchered Street Fighter Character's movie. They had a good chance to make something great but they failed. As a true fan of Street Fighter this really makes me sad. Stop making me sad Hollywood.

reviews.review_title: This makes the 1994 title look like an Oscar nominee.
reviews.content: One star is being generous.I can't even express in words how bad this movie was. There is no sense to the plot what-so-ever. Why is her father kept alive? What are those "energy balls" Gen show her? How does she learn to perform such things? Why did I spend 90 minutes watching this terrible film?This is a RIP OFF. They used the title "street fighter" to attract fans, in order to make money. I really hope the production & publishing cost more than the lame &12 mil it earned (12?? really???).The worst part of the movie, is the hot detective / "cool" interpool guy plot. Seriously, what are they doing? What are they donating to the movie? Nothing.Seriously, don't watch this movie. You're better off watching youtube - whatever you'll see there is better than this movie.And I'm not joking.

reviews.review_title: A Review and History
reviews.content: This Title didn't necessarily grab my interest right away, since most Live Action Game movies have not been the best (ex: Super Mario Bros, Double Dragon, Mortal Kombat, Doom, BloodRayne anyone?). Yet, in the true nature of being a Street Fighter fan, I set out to see it with optimism.The cast members in my opinion were hastily chosen. I suspect the choosing process may have revolved around what faces are pretty and readily recognizable. Though some actors have worked on other projects before, (American Pie, Smallville, Desperate Housewives, Terminator Salvation to name a few) realize that a decent cast with terrible writing a good movie does not make.The writing ugh... seriously? Aside from the main plot itself, which couldn't decide whether it was a heart felt family vengeance film, a B Rated action film, or a slaughter house caught on tape (Chun-li shooting someone in the chest point blank/ M. Bison boxing with a corpse), the banter between actors was less then imaginative.The actors themselves barely resembled the game players at all. Even giving Kristin Kreuk the time tested Chun-li hair buns, I never felt a connection with anyone. They were not the part, they were simply playing the part, and this can make the film seem flat, no matter how many fighting scenes or Special Effects you put in.Gen is a terminally ill assassin, who seeks to fight Akuma one last time before he dies. Did I also forget to mention HES OLD, possibly in his 70's, they didn't emphasize that enough. He felt more like Chun-li's BFF then a mentor and instructor.The sexual tension between Charlie Nash and C. Viper (Det. Maya Sunee) was also poorly thought out. The scene in the car as they are staking out Balrog could've been written by a 13 year old. I was also terribly disappointed when I heard the name 'Nash' as he walked out of the car, all I could think about was.. 'Where is his Vest, the glasses, his blond hair?' The one liners were also in poor taste. 'I want you to send Bison a message. Tell him the schoolgirl's grown up.', when he repeats it back to her, she's on the floor with 5-6 guns to her face.I would recommend this movie only to those that have a love for the franchise name 'Street Fighter' and want to say they have seen and played anything connected to that name.I give this film a D. It only did not receive an F because it was called Street Fighter.

reviews.review_title: Definition of a bad crossover.
reviews.content: Okay... yes everyone hated that Van Damme street fighter but didn't people realise it kept more to the original storyline with most characters... JUMPING STRAIGHT TO VEGA. Would be the obvious one. Come on changing the reason on why he wears the mask completely messes up his history.The acting was decent and the Gen and Chun-Li scenes were the only good parts of the film. However why is it that Charlie Nash is included in a side-plot that is neither funny nor interesting.I'm rating this 1 due to the fact it is actually worse than the Van Damme version.

reviews.review_title: Weak Movie
reviews.content: Its nothing like the game or the street fighter 2V episodes. Chun-Li is Japanese but looks more American than anything. Vega comes out for like 2 minutes and dies, and he doesn't even look Spanish, he has black hair when in the games and shows he is always shown as a blonde. Bison's a little Irish guy. I thought the movie was going to be about all fighting & some good moves, spinning kicks, and people flying everywhere. The characters are nothing like they are described in the games and shows. and the fighting wasn't all that good either. I think this movie could have been better if they spent more time working on it. The game and cartoons are still cool though.

reviews.review_title: A few good fights and a terrible plot. Typical, really.
reviews.content: Plot Summary: Kristen Kreuk lends tired clichés to a montage depicting her childhood relationship with her father. Suddenly Balrog (Michael Clarke Duncan) bursts through the kitchen window, catches a can of frozen OJ that has been kicked at him, laughs maniacally and starts a fight with Chun-Li's (Kreuk's) father. Kung-fu ensues, and Bison reveals that he moves so quickly gusts of wind herald his arrival. Bison and Balrog kidnap Chun-Li's father. Fast forward: wealthy Juliard grad and concert pianist Chun-Li decides that some old lady's translation of a vague ancient scroll she received in the mail is a convincing argument for her to abscond to Bangkok to live on the street while she searches for some guy named Gen. Eventually Gen becomes her master, we discover her father is still alive and the financial backbone of Bison's criminal organization, the most unlikely interpol agent you ever could cast (Klein) is bumping rap music while maintaining a healthy sexual interest in a Thai detective (Bloodgood) and doing no useful police work, Chun-Li lures a lesbian to a bathroom to beat information out of her, Vega appears briefly, and the diabolical plot of Bison to tear down the slums of Bangkok and develop townhouses is revealed. Two Hadouken-like energy blobs are fired off in total.Good: Kreuk surprisingly, hearing her say "these streets" in a wistful tone particularly satisfying in a bad>good way. Some decent kung-fu, hilariously awful four man gun-circle around Kreuk which she dispatches handily by break dancing, Klein being a total weirdo, Klein noticing the most obviously placed bomb/wireless-router with an L.E.D glued onto the front ever and jumping out of the buildings as it explodes. Lots of heartless death. Kreuk/Lesbian hench-woman share strange courting ritual that resembles bad dancing.Bad: It's all bad in some respect.Ugly: Use of screen-time, involvement of police, bad guy's endgame, casting in general (not Kreuk), lack of commitment to either realism or "powers" of street fighters: instead movie treads awkward middle ground, Bison's backstory, Vega's character, the Hadouken-like energy ball thingy, cops losing a tail due to imposed make-out/cover-up of surveillance by Klein, Bison manipulates well-connected businessmen and crime bosses like they are twelve and openly confronts police forces with armed security forces bearing the logo of his company. In short the plot.Strangely watchable if you can remain un-phased by all the terrible things that make this a terrible movie in order to appreciate kreuk kicking ass and Klein sucking it in their respective roles.

reviews.review_title: Typical, thoughtless, gamer movie
reviews.content: It is almost criminal that a director, given the fan base, premise, and interesting character backgrounds/moves in advance to filming can produce such a steaming pile. This man had four aces and traded them away because he didn't understand the basic rules to five card stud.What the hell was with the story? M. Bison with children? Who the hell wants to see that? Chun li's three minutes of training was almost as much of a joke as casting the dude from American Pie as an interpol agent..What happened to the tournament.. you know.. the idea behind the game? Even the two mortal kombat movies got that much right. (I know at least the casting director saw those movies because Lou from MK is Gen) Worse, what the hell was with the fighting scenes.. Where is M. Bison's moves from the game, he does slides in the game, not standard martial arts, and where the hell was his Special MOVE? Worse, when do you see M. Bison with a bamboo stick in the game.. NEVER! Why is Vega such a push over.. why are the effects on chun-li's fireball so corny! It didn't look anything like the game, which is a fast-paced single motion fireball of chi and which could've been done aptly with today's cgi.The only thing worthwhile in this movie is a) the soundtrack (which was fitting), b) the cinematography (which was mostly fitting, good high key lighting, good color combination, fitting aura.. even though the Mise en Scene lacked originality or thought.. docks and guns.. really?) The casting is stupid (nobody looks like they should, or ACTS like they should.) The writing is corny, pretentious, and lacks ANY of the INTERESTING characters from the Street Fighter Game. The directing/editing was brilliantly as talentless as all these other elements. Too many dissolves. Too many pointless scenes. The inciting incident was stupid, as well as the plot.I could go on forever. To a person who paid 85 dollars to get the Street Fighter Championship and Hyper Edition on Sega Genesis when it first dropped, this movie is not just a disappointment, but a mind-boggling failure.

reviews.review_title: How is it possible?
reviews.content: This "movie" is dumb. I mean, really, really, really DUMB! The "plot" is so lame I can't even begin to describe it's lameness, the acting sucks like a Volta (especially the cops, God, it still gives me nightmares!), and worst of all - there's hardly any action or fight scenes in the movie at all. The few action scenes that are in there are so bad it's a relief when they're over (usually after 5 seconds), and everything in between is just unbearable to watch. I'd rather be water-boarded than watch this filth again. And one more thing : Justin Marks, if you read this (nothing personal) : STOP WRITING MOVIE SCRIPTS! I swear, if Sony let you ruin Shadow of the Colossus like you did with this movie I will set myself on fire outside your house. Besides, there IS already a king, and his name is Uwe Boll.

reviews.review_title: It's bad to the point where it hurts
reviews.content: The legend of Chun-Li focuses around Chun-Li (duh) in her journey to rescue her father and bring down the Shadaloo organization. This movie is so bad, I don't know where to start.. The script is so cheesy and corny; some of the characters are using clichés I just had to wonder out loud:"did he just say that?" and I mean In this one scene, Chun-Li wanted to do a research on Shadaloo, she just go to an internet café, sits on the computer and framing evidence just pop up  what did she write"stuff I can use against a worldwide organization trying to take over Bangkok"? And the movie is filled with this stuff... Basically, the whole movie feels like it was written by a fourteen years old kid, and while some of the fighting scenes are cool, they are not enough to hold the movie.The characters are another lame part in this train wreck: Nash is far over-acting and too corny. They turned Vega, a handsome matador, into a ridiculously low-pitched ugly Taboo, that more or less, got bitch-owned by Chun Li. Gen looks vital than ever, having him AGED BACKWARDS. Bison (Neal McDonough) is now a business man that runs an international crime organization, and still has time to practice the martial arts and moves-that-should-kill-you-but-you-just-bounce-right-back-up. And of course... Chun-Li... I mean SHUT UP! She's just blubbering the entire thing..."I was walking in Bangkok" I KNOW, I CAN SEE THAT!! And she doesn't even look Chinese!! What happened to her accent?? And who faints after beating the crap out of a group of thugs? This version of Chun-Li has no credibility what so ever. Balrog was the only character I found convincing, I mean Michael Clarke Duncan was perfect for this role, even thou his character was pretty flat. Come to think about they all were (despite some good actors).In conclusion, if you like the game DON'T watch it. In fact, if you love YOURSELVES don't watch it. Unless you're studying film and want to avoid all possible clichés, and see the definition for a bad film. And to sum it all up, when I finished watching this, i said to my friend "well... I've seen worse", so that's why I gave it 2 stars. (worse = Moral Kombat Annihilation. God, I feel sorry for Robin Shou)

reviews.review_title: Liked it when it ended.
reviews.content: I really do struggle to think of ANY good points from this laughable film. But bhoy can I think of bad ones: All but Kristin IMO are badly miss-cast from the game; which it partially is based on, seemingly only for attention. It could of been based on 'Streets Of Rage' and been none-the-wiser. Fight Scenes were typically poor given the dire directions this film partakes. Further all of the actual fights involved felt just odd and 'uncool' looking. Chuns unnecessary backflips over rooftops were funny. Dialogue is remarkably cheesy and even folly and awkward at times. It is so poor and offending to me and surely other fans of the game who are still waiting to see a decent Street Fighter movie. This is even worse than that other one apart from the strong hint of more to come involving a "Street Fighting Tournament with Ryu". Oh Kristin Kreuk is sooo Hot(suddenly thinking of them fireballs and how they were included as if an afterthought. So bad you will like it..when it ends. DO NOT SEE IT!

reviews.review_title: this is anything but a street fighter movie
reviews.content: there aWhen you see this movie you think of the game franchise and remember the good times you had with the game,and then think that the title could do some justice to them but the fist thing you can notice in the movie is the lack of street fighter characters but well it is the "legend of chun li" so it must be about her but then the story begins in a bad way afther some minutes of intro and when you see M.Bison un a suit and looking nothing like M.bison from the games then balrog is played by mike Duncan and i tought that was cool he fitted the role just fine but then in the whole movie he fought like a wrestler used guns and rocket launchers and did all kind of things except boxing properly like Balrog ,the vega in the movie was the worst impersonation of vega i have seen i think cosplayers in conventions do a better vega...re some support characters like the cops who don't really add any actually interesting dialogue to the movie the fights are alright but they have very little to do with the characters in the games the story about M.Bison origins is specially weak and in my opinion hilarious he steals some fish in the most pathetic way and then boom he has a girlfriend and nice clothes the movie development and dialogue in general just made me feel like laughing but that is just my reaction maybe the writers tought the focus point of the movie was to tell the tale of chun li's adventures in an "unique" way but it just backfired.

reviews.review_title: Bold but True Statement - Worse than the First
reviews.content: I actually created an IMDb account just to state how bad this movie was. The bigger Street Fighter fan you are, the more angry you will be at inconsistencies with the film. I knew it would be bad, but this was painful to watch.I don't consider these spoilers (but will leave the warning on just in case) but more of a vent. These are things you will pick up on and say "wtf?" There are more, but no need to spoil this already bad movie.1) Vega is an ugly looking Japanese guy instead of a handsome Spainard. 2) Chun-li's dad is not working for Interpol, but Nash is? 3) Gen never performs a fireball in any Alpha or other games...never. 4) Last I recall, Gen is not "old friends" with Bison. 5) There was no point in adding that random hot chick with a non-existent organization.Regardless, I stand by my summary that this is worse than the first as those actors at least looked much closer to the actual characters and there was much more action. All I could say after watching this was "I waited 15 years for this?!"

reviews.review_title: Great actors, BAAAD plot line..
reviews.content: As a fan of Street fighter games and the first movie with Van Dam (And a half-decent plot-line), this movie was a real disappointment.From start to finish i never got what the whole movie was about..The actors like Kristin Kreuk, Neal McDonough and Robin Shou would have made this movie look excellent, but the scripts left a lot to be desired.The action scenes were pretty good, unbelievable, but good, but what was up with those special effects? There were a lot of scenes that were very predictable, making the movie a bit too boring for me. Overall i give it a 4/10 since the actors made it look better than it was!

reviews.review_title: Worst representation of Streetfighter's Chun li
reviews.content: I've been a big fan of Chun li since 1994, and Kristen is NOT a good pick to represent Chun li at all! This movie somehow managed to have the weakest plot, poor directing, and bad casting all in one. Aside from having an anorexic actress playing the buff and powerful Chun li, the plot is so unforgivably predictable. At the very end, at least throw us fans a bone and put on the Chun li costum...Go watch this movie if you are NOT a fan of Chun-li, into skinny chick that pretend to throw a punch, bad and predictable plots, shallow and lame character development and BAD acting...Its not even worth it to download it, God forbid if you actually buy the DVD!
This made me appreciate what a MASTERPIECE the JC-VD movie was.

It absouletly sucked I hope the director never makes a movie looks like this. Shame on you, how could you wake up and decide to make a movie like this, just wow. Shame, Shame, Shame. I expected way more from a street fighter movie MORE ACTION, EXPLOSIONS, AND ACTION.

Street Fighter: Legend of Chun-Li is another example of a poorly adapted take on the iconic video game franchise and its characters. 

The acting ranged from poor to mediocre especially with Chris Klein's Nash and Neal McDonough's M. Bison, the martial arts was not well choreographed, the story and script were bland and uninteresting.

I've played the Street Fighter series for a long time and I have a general idea of the game's setting along with the characters' backstories and yet whoever wrote the film did not acknowledge and relate back to the source material.

Wow, actually cringe worthy... Were the actors actually instructed to do the worst most always job possible? In fact if they just make this movie derivative and directly copy another successful movie but with SF characters they would have done ten times better... And WTF is this soundtrack??? The crew needs to pay us for our time wasted hating a beloved iconic franchise

Better than the 94' version but still Not Good. Chris Klein & Neal McDonough are terribly miscast. Chun-Li is just ok and doesn't really have any chemistry with anyone. Everyone is honestly ok outside of the miscasting's but the miscasting's drag down the performances to subpar. The cinematography is ok and the fight scenes are generic and forgettable. So is the musical score as well. The editing and pacing are not good in this. This movie can't decide if it wants to be a Police thriller or Kung-Fu movie and really never makes the two work together. While there definitely is more focused a plot here than in 94' it still loses focus sometimes and it drags and never really keeps tension. I can definitely understand why hardcore Street Fighter fans hate this. But anyone else its just a subpar Action Movie. Skip This.

Street Fighter makes a comeback with this new film. Surprisingly, it's not as godawful as the original Jean Claude Van Damme movie. The cast is pretty decent, the story well-paced, and the action is professionally mounted. It's still junk, but at least it's competently-made junk. The skinny-minnie at the center of this, Kristin Kreuk, isn't exactly the most engaging leading lady, but she's cute and looks convincing in her fights and stunts. Chris Klein (of 'American Pie' fame) tries to show some edge as an Interpol agent but is too bland to pull it off. Exotic-looking Moon Bloodgood (is that her real name?) is more interesting as his partner. Neal McDonough, with his steel-blue eyes and white hair, is always a scary-looking villain. As is the man-mountain known as Michael Clarke Duncan. Robin Shou, who played Liu Kang in those 'Mortal Kombat' movies so long ago, has aged into a credible martial arts guru who trains our heroine. Director Andrzej Bartkowiak did 'Romeo Must Die,' 'Exit Wounds,' 'Cradle 2 the Grave,' and the movie version of 'Doom,' so don't expect much. The story is nothing more than a revenge tale, with masked thugs dressed in black as generic fighting foes. The dialogue and voice-over narration is laughably arch. In the end, though, this surpassed my expectations, if only a little
Spamming fireball moment
Not the greatest plot or acting but still entertaining 😂

Hmm, trying to think of what positive thing can I say about Chun Li? 🤔. Oh, I wish I could say this is the worst movie I've ever seen. That's positive, right? Oh, and I can't believe they wasted the perfect casting of Kristin Kreuk on this garbage.
Absolutely terrible movie, though Chris Klein did add some comedic relief with his unbelievably bad acting.

I like Kristin Kreuk, Robin Shou, and Michael Clarke Duncan they are the only thing that made made this movie better. However i did not see this movie as a Street Fighter movie The SG was so bad and Bison in this movie is not good. The action sequences, while not AS bad as I expected them to be, still came off as rather absurd. Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li: 5 out of 10: A Batman Begins style reboot for the Street Fighter series which up to this point consisted of one highly derided film released 15 years earlier. 

The Good: You know if you forget this is supposed to be a Street Fighter film (Not hard to do at all since outside of some the character names this really has nothing to do with Street Fighter) this really isn't that bad. Good production values and location shooting with the occasional action beat. Considering this is currently at number 76 of the 100 worst movies of all time on the IMDB list,  the low expectations do it some favors as well. Both Kristin Kreuk as the titular star and Moon Bloodgood as a detective are watchable and refreshing. In addition, Michael Clarke Duncan is clearly having fun and his enthusiasm is infectious. 

The Bad: Entire doctoral thesis has been written about all the things wrong with the movie. Among the various sins child actors that look nothing like their adult counterparts (to the point of being a clearly different nationality), Chris Klein is awful and drags down every scene he is in, Chris Klein is in way too many scenes, and the villain makes no sense.

The Ugly: Here we get to the crux of the hatred for this unremarkable action film. Street Fighter fans. This is, by any measure, a terrible adaptation of the source material. Now I have to admit my eyes glaze over when rabid fandoms go on the attack because the backstory written to sell some toys and fill five minutes of a twenty-four-minute cartoon is treated as if Moses himself brought it down from the mountain. (I am looking your way Transformers fans), but Street Fighter fans have an understandable beef.

As source material goes Street Fighter is a pretty thin gruel. Unlike many modern video games, Street Fighter has more in common with Pac-Man or Donkey Kong than say The Last of Us. You have colorful characters and a fighting tournament outside of that a screenwriter pretty much has carte blanche to do what he wants with the story. Guess what this movie does not have? If you said a fighting tournament and colorful characters guess what you win a prize.


In Conclusion: Clearly, the screenwriter had a Tomb Raider script sitting in a dusty drawer (The film makes much more sense as a Tomb Raider reboot than a Street Fighter one) and got a call from his agent. Meh, one video game is the same as another just change Lara Croft to Chun Li and change the Irish real estate mogul into Bison and we are good to go. No need to change the plot about the cave of soul cleansing or the mysterious scroll or the heroine living alone in the mansion with servants after her father's disappearance.

Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li is a 2009 martial arts action thriller film directed by Andrzej Bartkowiak, written by Justin Marks, and starring Kristin Kreuk, Neal McDonough, Michael Clarke Duncan, Chris Klein, Moon Bloodgood, Robin Shou, Taboo, Josie Ho, and Elizaveta Kiryukhina. The film is based on Capcom's Street Fighter video games and is a reboot of the 1994 film Street Fighter.

When she was younger, Chun-Li (Kristin Kreuk) witnesses the kidnapping of her father Xiang by the wealthy Irish crime lord M. Bison (Neal McDonough), the CEO of Shadaloo Headquarters. Years later, she goes into a quest for vengeance and becomes the famous crimefighter of the Street Fighter universe.

I was introduced to the Street Fighter universe when I bought Street Fighter IV for the Xbox 360 a few years earlier, and I loved it. A wide variety of characters, fun gameplay, inventive fighting styles and powers... it was pure awesomeness. I also bought the updated version of the game, Super Street Fighter IV, and I loved that even more.

In the summer of 2013, I rented the 1994 live-action Street Fighter film from Family Video. The Steven E. de Souza-written and directed film starred Jean-Claude Van Damme as Guile (tremendous miscast), Ming-Na Wen as Chun-Li, and Raul Julia as M. Bison (best part of the film). While very different from the games, I gotta admit, I had a bit of fun with this film. It's bad, yes, but I'd consider it a guilty pleasure. However, that film is Oscar-worthy cinema compared to this abomination.

If you thought the 1994 film was a terrible adaptation of the games, take a look at this shitstorm. This film rapes pretty much everything people loved about this franchise up the ass. Director Andrzej Bartkowiak (whose previous films I did enjoy) and screenwriter Justin Marks make absolutely no attempt to try to follow the games and that pisses me off.

The performances are awful, with the three exceptions being Neal McDonough, Michael Clarke Duncan, and Robin Shou. Despite his truly horrendous Irish accent, McDonough was trying very hard to make this generic, non-threatening bad guy work, and Shou was mildly entertaining as Gen. Sadly, Marks' dismally-penned script and Bartkowiak's tenuous, amazingly effortless direction prevent McDonough and Shou from being allowed to truly shine.

Michael Clarke Duncan as Balrog is admittedly a delight. You can tell he's having a blast playing this guy. Not to mention, Balrog is the only character who bears any resemblance to his video game counterpart. Kristin Kreuk is atrocious as Chun-Li, which is a real shame, given that I loved her as Lana Lang on Smallville. Her line delivery is just abysmal and she shows hardly any genuine emotion.

Moon Bloodgood is bland (although sexy) as Maya Sunee, who becomes Crimson Viper in the video games. Taboo as Vega is a tremendous miscast, one of the biggest in film history. However, the worst performance comes from Chris Klein as Charlie Nash (Blanka from the games). Klein looks beyond bored to be in this film and he sounds as if he's a petulant five-year-old doing a bad Christian Slater impersonation. Phenomenally awful.

If you watch this film expecting some bad-ass fight scenes, you'll be disappointed. The action scenes in this movie are pitiful. Andrzej Bartkowiak directs the action and fight scenes with no skill, effort, passion, or energy, and not to mention, they're very poorly edited by Derek G. Brechin and Niven Howie, and the choreography is nothing short of a joke. They even use Chun-Li's signature Spinning Bird Kick with truly deplorable results. However, the cinematography by Geoff Boyle is occasionally crisp, so there's that.

The whole affair is just a tired, generic mess all around. Stephen Endelman's musical score is insipid and flavorless beyond definition, there are countless martial arts and action film clichés, and there's not even a lick of originality and creativity to be found. The visual effects are spectacularly horrible. There's one bit five minutes into the movie where Chun-Li's father attacks a guy by using a bottle of wine as a water pistol, with the wine being as clear as water. The CGI for the wine is just... blecch. I mean, dear God.

Justin Marks' screenplay is reprehensible. Hardly any character development, really god-awful dialogue, and a story so redundant, outrageously ridiculous, and nonsensical you'll want to pull your hair out. Not to mention, the tone is completely wrong. It takes itself so goddamn seriously. What dumb-ass wanted a dark, gritty, more realistic version of Street Fighter? What the fuck.

FINAL SCORE: 1/10

Ahhhh, takes me back to my secondary school lunch breaks where me and my friends used to sneak off and play 'Street Fighter' for half an hour on the Mega Drive. Sorry to see that not many of the characters from the original video game have made an appearance in this film though, probably because the majority of it is based around Chun Li as the title suggests. It's basically about her fight to rescue her father, who was kidnapped by the big boss himself, Major Bison - and what a formidable baddy he is too, it always took me hours to beat him up on the final stages of the game! Along the way, there are several battles and Kung fu style fight scenes as you would expect, which to their credit attempt to mirror the classic attributes of their individual game characters. There are also a number of not so combative cast members who I presume have been employed to boost ratings I.e. Chris Klein from American Pie, Taboo from the Black Eyed Peas, and the late Michael Clarke Duncan, who performs the very fitting character of Balrog, a big meathead boxer. It's good harmless fun, but probably not recommendable if you are genuinely after a quality Kung fu film and have no prior knowledge of the video game. Even despite my familiarity with it, it's still quite a disappointment to see such an absence of classic characters, plus the key battles were all a bit of an anticlimax as some of the so called invincibles were beaten after just a few hits, including the big man Bison himself! I guess when you employ non-combat actors to perform kick-ass roles, their fight scenes are always going to be a tad limiting though! Still, I'll always love bashing away aimlessly at the control pad in a game of 'Street Fighter', just won't ever be as crazy about this movie!

This movie was so bad that I have to give the Jean-Claude Van Damme movie Oscars for being a success and yet not getting much credit. The story was boring, there were rarely any action scenes in it and when there were any, they looked like they were choreographed by an 8-year old, even the montage. The music wasn't even that catchy, the scenes felt like they had been ripped off another movie and the actors we like are wasted and the ones we don't should be doomed. While the games focused on Ryu and Ken and sort of Chun-Li because she was the lead actress in the games, this movie focuses heavily on her only as the title says so. Kristin Kreuk looks nothing like Chun-Li and whenever she does, she's either not fighting or not wearing her blue outfit and whenever she does fight, it doesn't look the least bit realistic infact all the stunt choreography/ fight scenes are horrible and there's only like 3 or five of them including a training montage so that we can build up to the big vengeful climatic battle.  In this movie, Chun-Li's a pianist which is an even worst origin than a reporter who's seeking revenge on M.Bison because they captured her parents well at least they got that right. There is one scene where I thought she actually looked like Chun-Li and she was doing this mystical ball kind of thing that her master taught him and yet she wasn't wearing her blue costume and her hair was in a pony tail which is what killed it off. Ming-Na Wen who voiced Mulan played Chun-Li in the 1994 version looked more like Chun-Li and she didn't even need the blue outfit. Nash played by Oz from American Pie is supposed to be Guile's friend or brother but has turned into one of the most annoying characters in video game history. What happened to the goody-goody singing sportsman Chris Fucking Ostriecher from American Pie? He's now turned into total annoyance but wait, Tara Reid being a cliche scientist in Alone In The Dark is much worst. He is the lead actor and he doesn't do jack shit other than spew annoying single-dialogues and be little-useful in the climax with one pistol again that killed it off. Neal McDonough who plays M.Bison can't even feel Raul Julia's shoes. Do you know what Raul had he had to go through before when he got the role of M.Bison? It was requested by his children so he chose it as his last movie ever plus he even died before the film's release and so the film was dedicated to him. That was a lot of hard work put into one man in one movie. Here it's the total opposite. At least that movie got his origins right, In this he's a fucking businessman! He doesn't even look like M.Bison; Instead he looks like Tony Stark's stepfather. Robin Shou who played Liu Kang in Mortal Kombat plays Chun-Li's master Gen and that's another talent wasted. Robin, you're better off as Liu Kang. Go back to Mortal Kombat, you're better off there and don't even bother if the special effects in MK2 are one of the worst, you can survive that movie, but you can't survive this. This is why a film should not be adapted from a video game. The film is a sequel to another video-game adaptation called Street Fighter, that being said we know that we are heading towards a disaster. The plot of this film is about Chun-Li a young pianist whose father is kidnapped by a dude named Bison. As Chun-Li grows she realizes who are the men whom captured his father and now she must learn martial arts to hunt down the men whom took a way his father. Chun-Li goes to Bangkok and finds how much terrible the citizens are living with Bison's Iron Fist. 
The film is freaking terrible. Is not that there is a lot of action and little story, is that the action sequences are poor, dull and surprisingly boring. There's a scene in this movie in which the girl jumps from one house to another and you can clearly see the cable on top of her. None of the fight scenes made me say wow except at the climax when she breaks the neck of a person. That is it! Another scene is with Chun-Li fighting against another woman (whom supposedly is one of the greatest fighters in the video game) and Chun-Li only grabs her hair for like 5 seconds and instantly the lady gives up. There is no hype in this movie everything in this movie goes to fast or happens absolutely nothing. 
The movie is short and they did something terrible with the pace. The film went just too fast for example that dad is fighting a couple of bad guys, they look really strong. Then Mr. Bison comes in, which looks as the weakest of all the bad guys, and the father instantly gives up. With no struggle at all, just like that he gives up. We don't see Mr. Bison fight until the end of the movie and he is supposed to be the Big Bad Boss of this entire movie but he isn't. He is not even menacing, he tells the protagonist: "You will not stop me." In the most hideous, dullest way I have ever seen in my entire life.  
The problem with video-game films is that they look like video-games and we are not here to waste our money to watch video-games, we are here to watch movies and this is not a movie. Films should have characters, a plot, cool action sequences but this did not buy anything that had in this movie. The screenplay is just terrible up to the point you want to vomit. It did not explain everything what was going on and you felt completely alienated. Another problem with video-game films is that there's nothing fresh in them. Absolutely nothing. I mean is like I was watching another dumb and pathetic kung-fu movie. 
What I like about this film is that it meet with my expectations. I thought this movie was going to be bad and it was a bad movie. What I like about this movie is that it had a narrator so that we don't get lost while watching this movie. The film has a story is about justice, about finding your father and don't let nothing stand in your way. This film could have been much better. 
This film was directed by Andrzej Bartkowiak whom most of his films are about action movies. So don't expect to see a good film about this guy. He seriously need to get better on his movies, even do he is more of a cinematographer than a director. The directing was this film was really terrible up to the point that makes you want to leave the film. 
I would recommend this movie to people that love video-game films because it lacks everything else. I mean if you like films with dull and boring action sequences then this is the film for you guys because this film really bored me to death.

An entry in the somewhat shakey Street Fighter film series, The Legend of Chun Li fails to deliver great action, spectacular fights and enough respect for the Street Fighter Universe. Things are not explained well with the prime example being a magic ball of energy. The question of whether or not this is possible in the film's realm isn't answered. The storyline is weak and choppy with the objective of the film hardly being clear at all. Certain characters aren't explained at all and there is hardly any character development for most of the characters. Some fight scenes are too short and should have been drawn out. There are certain things that confuse viewers who aren't familiar with the Street Fighter Universe/film series. Instead of making a really good film that fits well within the SF Universe, they made an average if not poor film. It is however somewhat connected to other films in a way with the mention of a fighter named Ryu in Japan. Robin Shou is a joy to see back in action and on screen. Kristin Kreuk shows she can step out of her Lana Lang shoes (Smallville TV Show) and kick ass.

Concert pianist/martial arts expert: that's a pretty absurd notion of being multi-talented, but for a film like "Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li", musicianship serves as shorthand for character development. Unfortunately, the girl's piano career is subordinated as a tangent, in favor of her other, more kinetic pursuit. When Chun-li(Kristin Kreuk) goes underground in Thailand, the concert pianist explains that she has to forget her past, in order to become one with Bangkok. How convenient for the film's cross-purposes. Instead of being one of the common people(like the slumming rich girl in Pulp's "Common People": Chun-li's rich, too; she says goodbye to her servants before going "Bangkok Forgetful"), Chun-li could have stayed off the streets by playing the piano in some dive(and evoke Francois Truffaut's "Tirez sur le pianiste"). But that won't do; after all, "Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-li" has no real aspirations of being a proper movie. It's pleased as punch with its essentiality of cheesy and uninspired fight sequences under the adulterated facade of girl power. Having the accomplished girl shed her identity just makes it easier for the film to ply its patriarchial bent. Sure, Chun-li kicks ass, but she's under the tutelage of a man. How do you say "To Sir With Love" in Mandarin? So the film takes away her best asset: her fingers. rt_summary: In Bangkok, Bison (Neal McDonough), a crime boss, and his henchmen (Michael Clarke Duncan, Josie Ho, Taboo) begin a bid for power in the city's slum, crushing everyone who gets in their way. As the violence escalates, a team of heroes emerges to bring Bison to justice. Fighting on the side of good are Chun-Li (Kristin Kreuk), martial-arts master Gen (Robin Shou), Interpol agent Charlie Nash (Chris Klein) and his partner, Maya Sunee (Moon Bloodgood).
